page.title: 08HOUSING IN THE AREA
page.content: Many of the houses in our area date from 1-2 hundred years ago when the villages were at their most prosperous with quarries, the brewery and the coal mines. With the decline of these many fell into disrepair. However with improved transport from cars, many people now chose to live in the villages and there has been a large amount of new, high quality building in the last 30 years, while older properties have been renovated. Most old buildings are of local grey limestone, sometimes dressed but often random rubble. Roofs are of red clay pantiles. Modern buildings are nearly all infills between older buildings. Each village has one council estate all built prior to 1950. 4 large country houses remain in Oakhill and Ashwick, 2 are private houses, 1 a museum and the last a restaurant.
